page.title: 20ECOLOGY
page.content: A feature of this intensively cultivated area is the lack of land which is in a relatively wild state, considerably reducing its wildlife potential. The churchyard has not been sprayed and still has a fairly typical grassland flora, but over-zealous mowing, especially in spring is reducing some species. Maidenhair spleenwort fern (Asplenium adiantum nigrum) has persisted on the church tower for at least 150 years. A small stretch of disused railway line in the north of the parish has some chalk plants, survivors of the now ploughed grassland of the last century. Hedgehogs, moles, rabbits, grey squirrels and small rodents are frequent and foxes are sometimes seen. Winter bird visitors include flocks of curlew and hunting hen harriers with several hundred geese on fields.
